newsitem.title: USA: Dunedin, Fla., mulls bond financing for Jays arena.
newsitem.headline: Dunedin, Fla., mulls bond financing for Jays arena.

text.p: The budget director for Dunedin, Fla., has suggested using tax-exempt bond financing if the city proceeds with $3.4 million of upgrades at the spring training facility used by the Toronto Blue Jays, the Tampa Tribune reported Friday.
Budget director Dan Zantop said taxable financing at 8.25 percent interest would cost about $5.9 million over 15 years or $6.8 million over 20 years.

But if the project qualifies for tax-exempt bonds, the interest rate would be lowered to about 5.25 percent, cutting the cost by $1 million to $1.4 million depending on the life of the bonds, Zantop told a task force that is trying to keep the team's spring training camp in Dunedin.
The team is seeking a practice field and training facilities adjacent to Dunedin Stadium.
The facility has not previously qualified for tax-exempt financing, which requires that the facility be used by the public at least 75 percent of the time.

Zantop said the renovation project probably would qualify if the city follows a task force recommendation to build a cloverleaf configuartion of four fields, which could be used by the public when the Blue Jays are not in spring training.
The team's contract with Dunedin runs through 1999 and the city is negotiating to renew the contract.
